contents.raw_html_text:
Check out our new Mountain Bike Skills Course located at the end of Hailes Cave Road. Designed for mountain bikes, the course features trails with varying terrain including pump tracks and jumps. Helmets are required when riding in the park. Biking is permitted on all trails except for the Indian Ladder Trail and Escarpment Trail.


Looking for a smoother ride? A paved one mile bike trail was recently completed around the visitor center. This wide trail is ideal for bicycles and strollers. Please be aware of other visitors and road crossings when biking in the park.

We look forward to opening a recreational rock climbing course soon. You will need a park permit to rock climb in Thacher Park. Please visit the front desk for more information and updates to the development of the course.


Be aware that recreational rock climbing requires proper gear, vast experience, and should never be attempted alone. Note that recreational rock climbing does not include rappelling over the cliff.

contents.right_image_uri: Thacher Indian Ladder Picnicers on RimTrail-0010_1505166409.jpg
contents.raw_html_text:
Pavilions and tent rentals are available seasonally and can be reserved through the park office. There are nine rental spaces available for parties of varying size. Please see the front desk for more information.


Planning a birthday party, wedding, family reunion, or other special event? Be sure to reserve your space in advance with the park and procure the necessary special event permits.


Note that Thacher Park is a carry-in, carry-out facility; you must take your trash with you when leaving the park. Help keep your park beautiful.

Thompson's Lake Campground is a five minute drive from Thacher Park. The campground offers up to 140 sites and includes restrooms and bathing facilities, dumping station, and some sites with full electric hookups. During the summer months amenities include a lifeguarded swimming beach, playground, horseshoe pits, ball court, and nature trails. Reservations are recommended and must be made through www.ReserveAmerica.com.


Please note that grills and picnic areas are for camper use only. For day use grills and picnic tables, please visit Thacher Park.


Non-motorized boats are for rent at the campground during the summer season. A hand-launch area is located by the beach for canoes and kayaks. There is a DEC motorized boat launch for up to 15 horsepower motors located at the south end of Thompson's Lake off of Thompson's Lake Road.

Disc golf is a family friendly activity that combines the setup of a golf game with the skill of disc tossing. The park's 18 basket Sky View disc golf course begins at Hailes Cave Road.


Bring your own discs and other equipment for playing. Maps and score cards of the course are available at the front desk. Please look before your toss. Discs that are specially designed for disc golf are available at any sporting goods store.

There are plenty of opportunities to watch our feathered friends at the park. During the fall season, hawks, falcons, eagles, and other raptors can be seen at the cliff's edge as they migrate south.


Check out open fields near the Nature Center for bluebirds, wooded areas for warblers, and if you are lucky, the cliff's edge for peregrine falcons!


For more information on birds and other wildlife, visit the Emma Treadwell Thacher Nature Center, a five minute drive from here.


Please be respectful of birds and all wildlife. Do not harass, feed, or disturb animals in the park; this is their home.

Hunting is a permitted activity in Thacher Park in the northern area only. Please visit the front desk for more information about getting a permit, hunting boundaries, and seasons. A valid NYS hunting license and park specific permit is required in all state parks that allow hunting.


A fishing area is accessible at Thompson's Lake Campground. Perch, pickerel, bass, and trout are regular catches. All fishermen age 16 and older must have a valid NYS fishing license on their person at all times. During the winter, check out the Ice Fishing Contest at Thompson's Lake.


Please be cautious when fishing near others. Fishing is prohibited on beaches and near the boat launch.

Winter is a great time to explore the trails in Thacher Park, with the exception of the Indian Ladder trail which is closed from mid-November through April for safety reasons.


Rent snowshoes at the Emma Treadwell Thacher Nature Center or bring your own snowshoes or cross-country skis to explore during our snowy season. Be aware that winter weather, wind, and temperatures can be more severe here in the park than in the lower Capital Region. Be cautious as trails may be coated in ice.


Snowmobiling is permitted in Thacher Park. Please stay on designated trails and use caution when crossing roads. Secondary snowmobile trails in Thacher Park connect to the greater corridor trail system that traverses much of New York State.

Looking for a family treasure hunt that involves hiking and a GPS? Thacher Park has several geocaches hidden throughout the park and campground. From May through October, participate in the Regional Geocache Challenge to expand your hunt for geocaches to over 15 parks and historic sites.


For more information on the Geocache Challenge and geocaching rules, please ask at the front desk.

There are playgrounds throughout the park at many of the picnic areas. Visit the Horseshoe II picnic area for a zip line for children under 12. Coming fall 2017- a new playground at the base of the Visitor Center featuring a slide, rock scramble, rope bridge, crawl tunnel, and children's rock climbing wall. Please remember; there is no smoking at playgrounds.


Also coming soon- Wild Play Adventure Course. An adventure course for all ages is in development at the Yellow Rocks Picnic Area. Ask at the front desk for more information and updates on the adventure course's development.

There are 25 miles of trails to enjoy in forested areas of the park or along the Helderberg Escarpment. For those that would like to enjoy a view of the Hudson Valley, Capital Region, and surrounding mountains, the Escarpment Trail is an easy walk.


For those that are looking for a more adventurous hike, take a walk down the Indian Ladder Trail. This popular trail winds along the Helderberg escarpment giving close up views to the limestone layers and ancient fossils.


Please note that the Indian Ladder Trail is closed for safety reasons from mid-November through April. During the wet season and after heavy rain, walk under a waterfall. Please be cautious and stay on the trail as there are steep drop offs and slippery spots.


If you are looking for trails less traveled, visit the northern section of the park for more wooded hikes and additional spectacular views at High Point and Hang Glider's Point.
